utterances: While you were mayor of Burlington, Vt.
- right?
Yes.
Yes.
Is this when this - you released a folk album.
That was a great band.
And they said hey Bernie, you know, why don't you join us?
Big mistake.
Big mistake.
Yeah.
(LAUGHTER)
As you will hear if you play this.
Let's - well, let's hear really quick.
And you tell us if you think this was a big mistake.
(Singing) As I went walking that ribbon of highway I saw above me that endless skyway.
(LAUGHTER)
There you go.
(APPLAUSE)
How in God's name did you and your staff find that?
Yeah.
I really tip my cap to our researchers who were digging stuff up like that.
And I also tip my cap to Bernie Sanders for having a good sense of humor about, you know...
Sounding like that.
...Yeah.
Sounding like that (laughter).
I will say the hardest thing I've found with interviewing politicians is the amount you have to jump in and cut them off.
I'm sure you have found this as well.
Yeah.
Because politicians if given time will talk without interruption up until you have to say, you know, thanks for stopping by (laughter).
Yeah, you know, I feel like you can probably call BS and stop a candidate in a way that I probably can't.
I feel like our roles are a little different somehow.
Maybe.
But I think that you sort of have the gravitas of being part of NPR.
Whereas I sometimes - when I'm sitting there, I'm thinking, am I about to interrupt a senator?
Am I - is this what I'm about to do?
And I think that'll just come with time and realizing that for the benefit of the show and for the benefit of them it's probably better to cut them off and move on to a new thought.

Does that setting, you know, your late night desk and sort of sitting there on a comfy chair and sort of knowing that you're in sort of a more comic role - do you feel like it disarms candidates when we get to see a different side of them that we just really don't usually?
You know, it's different for everybody.
Some show up with a lot of prepackaged jokes (laughter) that they are going to...
You can just tell.
You can just...
...They're going to get them out hell or high water.
It doesn't matter how much they sort of are (laughter) squeezing that square peg into a round hole.
(Laughter) Is there one that comes to mind?
I would say that Lindsey Graham, if you looked back at that tape, definitely had some jokes that were ready to go.
(SOUNDBITE OF TV SHOW, ""LATE NIGHT WITH SETH MEYERS"")
You believe in climate change.
You believe it's man - it's caused by man.
Are you surprised that so many in your party refused to accept this?
Well, I'm not a scientist.
Which is what everyone says.
And do you know why I can say that?
Because I'm not.
There you go.
(LAUGHTER)
I made a D in science.
You know why I made a D?
Why?
My teacher said she's never given an F.
Oh.
(LAUGHTER)

Ever a moment when you are sitting there on your show and you have a politician, and, I mean, it's just so painful and dreadful because you are, like, this is not funny, I am not getting this person to be funny, I'm not being - I can't be funny because of this person, like, it's too serious - this is just falling apart?
Yes.
OK.
There have been a few times.
But again - and I don't want to put that entirely on the politician.
You know, again, I'm fairly new at this as well.
And certainly you get the least amount of reps with political guests.
And that's why it's really fun when you have somebody like, you know, I thought, you know, Bernie was a lot of fun, and I thought Ted Cruz was a lot of fun.
Well, I - we've only done it a couple of times (laughter).
I went day drinking - my brother was in New York this summer so we did a segment where we went to Brooklyn and drank in the afternoon.
And then I did it again with my mother.
OK.
I'll put you on the spot - politics completely aside...
Yes.
...The candidate who you would most want to go day drinking with - candidate you would least want to go day drinking with.
Oh, that's interesting.
Well look I think I'd like to go day drinking in New York City with Donald Trump.
OK.
I feel we'd get into all of the best places.
That's probably true.
